question:
Which of the following places is related to Gandhi’s Satyagraha of the year 1917?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Champaran Satyagraha (1917) was Mahatma Gandhi’s first civil disobedience movement in India.
  • It took place in Champaran district (present-day Bihar), where indigo farmers were being forced by British planters to grow indigo under the exploitative Tinkathia system.
  • Gandhi was invited by Rajkumar Shukla, a local farmer, to take up the cause.
  • Gandhi used non-violent protest and legal inquiry, which led to the abolition of the Tinkathia system.

Additional Information:

  • The success of this movement marked Gandhi’s emergence as a national leader.
  • Other early movements led by Gandhi:
    • Ahmedabad Mill Strike (1918) – related to textile workers
    • Kheda Satyagraha (1918) – related to peasants unable to pay taxes due to crop failure
    • Bardoli Satyagraha (1928) – led by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, not Gandhi

question:
Who was the Viceroy of India when Mahatma Gandhi started Dandi March on 12 March 1930?

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Dandi March or Salt March began on 12 March 1930 and was led by Mahatma Gandhi as a part of the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • At that time, the Viceroy of India was Lord Irwin (tenure: 1926–1931).
  • The march was a protest against the British monopoly on salt and the salt tax imposed on Indians.
  • Gandhi marched from Sabarmati Ashram to Dandi, covering around 240 km in 24 days, and broke the salt law on 6 April 1930.

Additional Information:

  • The Dandi March became a symbol of non-violent resistance and inspired millions to join the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • It drew international attention to British oppression in India.
  • Later in 1931, Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed as a result of negotiations.

question:
In which year was the Gandhi-Irwin Pact signed?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed in the year 1931 between Mahatma Gandhi and the then Viceroy of India, Lord Irwin.
  • This pact marked a truce between the British government and the Indian National Congress, bringing a temporary halt to the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • As part of the agreement, Gandhi agreed to suspend the movement and participate in the Second Round Table Conference in London.
  • In return, the British agreed to release political prisoners and allow peaceful picketing of liquor and foreign cloth shops.

Additional Information:

  • The pact was signed on 5 March 1931.
  • Despite the agreement, the Second Round Table Conference (1931) ended in failure, and the movement resumed later.
  • This was a key moment in India’s freedom struggle, showing Gandhi’s leadership in negotiating directly with British authorities.

question:
In the second Round Table Conference, Mahatma Gandhi represented which of the following parties?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Communist Party of India
option_3: All India Forward Block
solution:
• The Second Round Table Conference was held in London in 1931 as part of the British efforts to discuss constitutional reforms in India.
  • Mahatma Gandhi attended this conference as the sole representative of the Indian National Congress.
  • His participation was a result of the Gandhi-Irwin Pact (March 1931), which allowed for the suspension of the Civil Disobedience Movement and Gandhi's participation in the talks.
  • Gandhi presented the Congress’s demand for complete independence (Purna Swaraj) and rejected the idea of separate electorates for minorities, which created friction with other delegates.

Additional Information:

  • Unlike the First Round Table Conference (1930), where Congress did not participate, Gandhi’s presence in the second conference drew global attention.
  • The conference ended without any major agreement, leading to resumption of the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • The Third Round Table Conference (1932) was held without Congress participation again.

question:
Which important event that started in 1930 played a significant role in motivating and mobilizing Indians to join the non-violent movement for independence?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Salt Satyagraha, also known as the Dandi March, began on 12 March 1930 and was a crucial part of the Civil Disobedience Movement.
  • Led by Mahatma Gandhi, it was a non-violent protest against the British monopoly on salt and the salt tax, which affected all Indians, especially the poor.
  • Gandhi marched from Sabarmati Ashram to Dandi (around 240 km) and broke the salt law on 6 April 1930 by making salt from seawater.
  • The movement attracted massive national participation and became a symbol of non-violent resistance.

Additional Information:

  • The Salt Satyagraha inspired millions of Indians across regions to break unjust British laws.
  • It gained international attention, strengthening India’s freedom movement.
  • This movement marked a turning point in transforming the Indian National Congress into a mass-based political force.

question:
Which of the following leaders had gone to Lucknow to invite Mahatma Gandhi to see the plight of the peasants in Champaran?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The person who approached Mahatma Gandhi to highlight the suffering of indigo farmers in Champaran (Bihar) was Raj Kumar Shukla, a local peasant and freedom fighter.
  • He met Gandhi in Lucknow in 1916 during the Congress Session and persistently requested him to visit Champaran.
  • Impressed by his determination, Gandhi finally agreed and visited Champaran in 1917, which led to the launch of the Champaran Satyagraha—Gandhi’s first civil disobedience movement in India.

Additional Information:

  • The farmers in Champaran were being forced to grow indigo under the Tinkathia system by British planters.
  • The success of this movement helped Gandhi earn the trust of the masses and brought him into the national political spotlight.
  • Leaders like Rajendra Prasad, J.B. Kripalani, and Anugrah Narayan Sinha later joined the Champaran effort.

question:
Mahatma Gandhi called a halt to the Non-Cooperation Movement after the Chauri Chaura incident. Where among the following places is Chauri Chaura located?

Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• The Chauri Chaura incident occurred on 4 February 1922 in the town of Chauri Chaura, located in the Gorakhpur district of Uttar Pradesh.
  • During a protest as part of the Non-Cooperation Movement, a violent clash broke out between protesters and police.
  • The crowd set fire to a police station, resulting in the death of 22 policemen.
  • In response to this violence, Mahatma Gandhi immediately called off the Non-Cooperation Movement, emphasizing his unwavering commitment to non-violence (ahimsa).

Additional Information:

  • Gandhi believed that violence was against the principles of the movement and feared it would derail the moral foundation of India’s struggle for independence.
  • Many leaders like Subhas Chandra Bose and Jawaharlal Nehru were disappointed by the sudden withdrawal.
  • Gandhi was later arrested and imprisoned for his role in the movement.

question:
The result of which of the following movements/satyagrahas was the abolishment of the Tinkathia System under which the farmers were asked to cultivate indigo in 3/20th of their holdings?

Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 3)
solution:
• The Champaran Satyagraha (1917) was the first major non-violent civil disobedience movement led by Mahatma Gandhi in India.
  • It was launched in the Champaran district of Bihar, where indigo cultivators were oppressed by the Tinkathia system.
  • Under this system, farmers were forced to cultivate indigo on 3/20th (15%) of their landholdings, often at unprofitable rates and under coercion by British planters.
  • Gandhi investigated the issue and used legal and peaceful protest methods, leading to the abolition of the Tinkathia system.

Additional Information:

  • The success of the Champaran Satyagraha marked Gandhi’s rise as a national leader in Indian politics.
  • It involved support from leaders like Rajendra Prasad, J.B. Kripalani, and Braj Kishore Prasad.
  • The British government was compelled to accept the farmers' grievances and introduce reforms in their favor.

question:
Gandhiji gave his slogan of ‘Do or Die’ during which of the following Movements/Satyagrahas?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 4)
solution:
• The slogan "Do or Die" was given by Mahatma Gandhi during the launch of the Quit India Movement on 8 August 1942.
  • This powerful phrase symbolized the urgency and intensity of the demand for complete independence from British rule.
  • The movement was launched in Mumbai at the All India Congress Committee session, and it called upon Indians to act decisively and non-violently to drive the British out of India.

Additional Information:

  • The British responded by immediately arresting Gandhi and other Congress leaders.
  • Despite the lack of central leadership, the movement witnessed widespread mass protests, strikes, and uprisings across India.
  • The Quit India Movement is considered the final major mass movement before independence.

question:
Vallabhbhai Patel and ________ helped Gandhi in Kheda by organising his tour of the villages and urging the peasants to stand firm against the government.

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel played a key role in the Kheda Satyagraha (1918), which was launched under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi.
  • Gandhi was assisted by Vallabhbhai Patel, along with Indulal Yajnik, Shankarlal Banker, and others.
  • Indulal Yajnik, a noted lawyer and nationalist from Gujarat, helped organize Gandhi’s village tours, communicated the message of resistance, and urged peasants to not pay taxes during the crop failure crisis.
  • The movement demanded tax suspension as crops had failed due to floods and famine-like conditions.
  • The success of the movement established Gandhi’s method of non-violent resistance and brought Patel into national prominence.

Additional Information:

  • The Kheda Satyagraha was one of the earliest peasant movements in India under Gandhian leadership.
  • After Kheda, Patel’s leadership and commitment earned him the title “Sardar”.
  • Jamnalal Bajaj was closely associated with Gandhi but more active in the Wardha region and later movements.

question:
On whose advice did Gandhi spend a year traveling around British India to know the people of India?

SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Mahatma Gandhi returned to India from South Africa in 1915.
  • He was advised by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, his political mentor, to spend a year traveling across India without participating in active politics.
  • Gokhale believed Gandhi should understand Indian society, diversity, and challenges before leading any national movement.
  • Gandhi took this advice seriously and observed real-life conditions of Indians, particularly peasants, laborers, and marginalized communities.
  • This period helped Gandhi form the foundation of his mass movement strategies.

Additional Information:

  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale was a senior leader of the Indian National Congress and founder of the Servants of India Society.
  • Gandhi called Gokhale his political guru and admired his moderate approach.
  • Shrimad Rajchandra was Gandhi’s spiritual mentor, not political.
  • Mohammad Ali Jinnah and Krishna Shankar Pandya were not involved in this early phase of Gandhi’s political journey.

question:
In which year was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi born?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi was born on 2nd October 1869 in Porbandar, which is in present-day Gujarat.
  • He later became the leader of the Indian freedom struggle and is widely known as the Father of the Nation.
  • His birth year, 1869, is historically significant and is a frequently asked fact in competitive exams.
  • The other options are incorrect:
    • (a) 1659 – Much earlier, unrelated
    • (c) 1889 – Year of birth of Jawaharlal Nehru
    • (d) 1879 – Year of birth of Albert Einstein

Additional Information:

  • Gandhi was born into a modest Vaishnav family; his father Karamchand Gandhi was a Diwan (chief minister).
  • Gandhi studied law in London and later developed his satyagraha methods in South Africa before leading Indian movements.

question:
Who was the founder of Harijan Sevak Sangh founded in 1932?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Harijan Sevak Sangh was founded by Mahatma Gandhi in 1932.
  • It was established to work for the upliftment of the 'Harijans' (a term Gandhi used for Dalits).
  • Gandhi founded it after the Poona Pact (1932) with Dr. B.R. Ambedkar regarding separate electorates.
  • The organization aimed to promote education, equality, and social inclusion for Dalits.
  • The headquarters of the Sangh was established in Delhi.
  • The first president of the Sangh was Amritlal Thakkar, also known as Thakkar Bappa.

Additional Information:

  • Harijan Sevak Sangh is still active and works for the welfare of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
  • The word Harijan means "Children of God", coined by Gandhi to replace caste-based derogatory terms.

question:
The famous scientist, Albert Einstein was inspired by whose idea on non-violence?

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Albert Einstein, one of the greatest physicists of the 20th century, deeply admired Mahatma Gandhi for his philosophy of non-violence (Ahimsa).
  • Einstein was not only inspired by Gandhi’s moral courage but also his commitment to truth and peaceful resistance.
  • Einstein once famously said, “Generations to come will scarce believe that such a one as this ever in flesh and blood walked upon this earth.”
  • This admiration highlights how Gandhi’s principles influenced not just political leaders but also global intellectuals and scientists.
  • Among the options, Mahatma Gandhi is the only modern figure associated directly with non-violent civil resistance that Einstein referred to.

Additional Information:

  • Gandhi’s method of Satyagraha (truth-force) was rooted in non-violence, influencing civil rights movements globally.
  • Other global leaders influenced by Gandhi include Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela.

question:
Who among the following returned his/her medal of Kaisar-i-Hind in 1920?

Higher Secondary 27/06/2023 (Shift - 3)
solution:
• Mahatma Gandhi returned the Kaisar-i-Hind medal in 1920 as a symbolic protest against the Jallianwala Bagh massacre (1919) and the repressive policies of the British government.
  • The medal was originally awarded to him by the British government in 1915 for his public service in South Africa.
  • After the massacre and enactment of the Rowlatt Act, Gandhi launched the Non-Cooperation Movement and returned this medal.
  • This act was a part of his larger strategy to renounce all British titles and honours in protest of colonial oppression.

Additional Information:

  • The Kaisar-i-Hind Medal was instituted by the British to honor public service in India.
  • Gandhi’s return of the medal marked a turning point in India's freedom struggle, encouraging others to renounce British honours.

question:
In 1918, Mahatma Gandhi successfully led a strike of ________.

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1918, Mahatma Gandhi led a successful strike of mill workers in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.
  • This was known as the Ahmedabad Mill Strike, where workers demanded a 35% wage hike due to rising inflation after World War I.
  • Gandhi acted as a mediator between the workers and the mill owners.
  • When negotiations failed, Gandhi encouraged workers to go on a peaceful hunger strike (fast unto death) to press their demands.
  • Eventually, the mill owners agreed to a 35% wage increase, marking it as Gandhi's first major industrial labour movement in India.

Additional Information:

  • This event strengthened Gandhi’s image as a mass leader and helped spread the use of non-violent resistance in labor movements.
  • The success also helped lay the foundation for organized labour rights in India.

question:
In Kheda, Gujarat, Patidar peasants organised non-violent campaigns against which of the following demands of the British?

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_4: Low price for crops
solution:
• In 1918, the Kheda Satyagraha was launched in Kheda district, Gujarat, under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, and others.
  • The Patidar peasants were unable to pay high land revenue due to crop failure and famine-like conditions.
  • The British government, however, refused to waive or reduce the revenue demand.
  • In response, peasants launched a non-violent campaign refusing to pay the tax until their demands were met.
  • This was one of the earliest examples of civil disobedience and collective peasant protest in India.

Additional Information:

  • The Kheda Satyagraha succeeded partially when the government agreed to suspend revenue collection for that year.
  • It marked Sardar Patel’s emergence as a strong national leader for peasant rights.

question:
When did depressed classes get the reserved seats in provincial and central legislative councils, but they were to be voted in by the General electorate?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• In September 1932, the Poona Pact was signed between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.
  • It was a historic agreement on the issue of separate electorates for the Depressed Classes (Dalits).
  • As per the Poona Pact, the Depressed Classes were granted reserved seats in both provincial and central legislatures,

    but they would be elected by the General Electorate through joint electorates.

  • This compromise replaced the British announcement in the Communal Award (August 1932) that had provided for separate electorates, which Gandhi strongly opposed.

Additional Information:

  • The pact increased the number of reserved seats for the Depressed Classes from 71 (as in Communal Award) to 147.
  • This event became a turning point in the political representation of Dalits within the Indian legislative framework.

question:
Gandhiji, aged ______, arrived in India in 1915 from South Africa.

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Mahatma Gandhi was born on 2nd October 1869.
  • He returned to India from South Africa in the year 1915.
  • His age at that time was 1915 – 1869 = 46 years.
  • Gandhi had spent 21 years in South Africa (1893–1914), where he developed his philosophy of Satyagraha (non-violent resistance).
  • Upon return, he began his active role in India’s freedom movement.

Additional Information:

  • Gandhi arrived in India on 9 January 1915, which is now observed as Pravasi Bharatiya Divas (NRI Day).
  • He was welcomed by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, who advised him to travel across India before entering active politics.

question:
Which of the following Indian freedom fighters said that "Be the change you wish to see in the world"?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The quote "Be the change you wish to see in the world" is widely attributed to Mahatma Gandhi.
  • This phrase reflects Gandhi’s philosophy of self-transformation as a means to achieve social and political change.
  • Though the exact wording may not be found in his writings, the essence of the quote aligns perfectly with his teachings.
  • Gandhi believed that individual responsibility and personal conduct are crucial in bringing about meaningful societal reform.

Additional Information:

  • Gandhi’s ideology of non-violence (Ahimsa) and truth (Satya) inspired civil rights movements across the world.
  • His influence extended beyond politics to ethical living, education, and community development.

question:
In which of the following years, did Subhas Chandra Bose refer to Mahatma Gandhi as the “Father of the Nation”?

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Subhas Chandra Bose referred to Mahatma Gandhi as the “Father of the Nation” in a radio address from Singapore in the year 1944.
  • He made this statement during a speech on 6 July 1944, while addressing Indians through the Azad Hind Radio.
  • Bose said: “Father of our Nation! In this holy war of India's liberation, we ask for your blessings and good wishes.”
  • This was the first recorded instance of Mahatma Gandhi being called the Father of the Nation.

Additional Information:

  • Though widely used, the title "Father of the Nation" has no official constitutional status in India.
  • Subhas Chandra Bose and Gandhi had ideological differences, yet Bose deeply respected Gandhi’s role in the freedom struggle.

question:
The All-India Khilafat Conference in November 1919 took place at:

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The All-India Khilafat Conference was held in November 1919 at Delhi.
  • The conference was organized to protest the harsh terms imposed on the Ottoman Empire after World War I, especially concerning the Khilafat (Caliphate).
  • It marked the beginning of the Khilafat Movement in India, which aimed to protect the position of the Ottoman Caliph, considered the religious head by Indian Muslims.
  • Mahatma Gandhi supported the movement and saw it as an opportunity to unite Hindus and Muslims in the struggle against British rule.
  • The Khilafat issue was soon merged with Gandhi's Non-Cooperation Movement (1920).

Additional Information:

  • Prominent Khilafat leaders included Maulana Mohammad Ali and Maulana Shaukat Ali.
  • The movement lost momentum after the abolition of the Caliphate by Mustafa Kemal Atatürk in 1924.

question:
Who among the following called Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose a patriot of patriots?

Graduate Level 03/08/2022 (Shift - 3)
solution:
• Mahatma Gandhi referred to Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose as a "Patriot of Patriots".
  • Gandhi used this term to acknowledge Bose's intense love for the nation, despite their ideological differences.
  • The statement was made after Netaji's reported death in 1945, as a tribute to his courage, sacrifice, and relentless struggle for India’s freedom.
  • Gandhi’s tribute reflected his respect for Bose’s dedication to the country, even though Bose followed a militant path unlike Gandhi’s non-violence.

Additional Information:

  • Subhas Chandra Bose believed in armed struggle and formed the Indian National Army (INA).
  • Despite differences, both Gandhi and Bose shared the common goal of India’s independence.

question:
Which of the following events occurred as an after-effect of the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (13th April 1919)?

SSC MTS 08/07/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: Hunger strike to settle disputes between the mill owners and the workers
option_2: Individual princes could sign a separate agreement with the British
option_3: Hunter Commission was appointed by the British Government
option_4: Popularisation of Charkha and Khadi and Jail Bharo by Congress volunteers
solution:
• The Jallianwala Bagh Massacre took place on 13th April 1919 in Amritsar, where General Dyer ordered open fire on a peaceful gathering, killing hundreds.
  • As a response to national and international outrage, the British Government appointed the Hunter Commission in October 1919 to investigate the incident.
  • The Hunter Commission included both British and Indian members, but it failed to hold General Dyer truly accountable, leading to further resentment.
  • The incident intensified the freedom movement and severely damaged the credibility of British rule in India.

Additional Information:

  • The massacre was a turning point that pushed leaders like Gandhi to move towards non-cooperation.
  • Rabindranath Tagore renounced his knighthood in protest.
  • It led to widespread national mourning and protests across India.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a reason for slowing down the Non-cooperation Movement?

SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Morning)
option_1: Due to the absence of alternative Indian institution, boycott of British institutions posed a problem.
option_2: Leaders of the movement shifted their focus towards domestic work thus created a void.
option_3: Many lawyers resigned but then absence of income for a longer period of time compelled them to rejoin.
option_4: Khadi cloth was often more expensive than mass-produced mill cloth and poor people could not afford to buy it.
solution:
• The Non-Cooperation Movement (1920–22) slowed down due to multiple practical and economic challenges, but option (b) is not among the key reasons.
  • (a) Boycotting British institutions became difficult because there were no strong Indian alternatives in education, courts, or administration.
  • (c) Many lawyers like Motilal Nehru gave up practice initially, but financial pressure forced some to return to work.
  • (d)Khadi was promoted, but it was costlier than machine-made cloth, making it unaffordable for the poor, limiting its mass appeal.
  • (b) However, the claim that leaders turned to "domestic work" and created a void is not factually strong or documented as a reason for the movement’s decline.

Additional Information:

  • The Chauri Chaura incident in February 1922, where a violent mob killed policemen, was the main immediate cause for Gandhi to call off the movement.
  • Gandhi believed in strict non-violence, and this incident convinced him the masses were not yet ready.

question:
In which of the following years was the civil disobedience campaign completely ceased?

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Civil Disobedience Movement was formally started by Mahatma Gandhi with the Dandi March on 12 March 1930 to break the Salt Law.
  • Though it was suspended and resumed multiple times, the movement continued in phases until it was officially withdrawn in 1934.
  • Gandhi called off the movement due to lack of mass support, increased British repression, and to focus on constructive programmes like Khadi, education, and village upliftment.
  • Thus, 1934 marks the complete cessation of the Civil Disobedience campaign.

Additional Information:

  • The movement had earlier seen the Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931) and participation in the Second Round Table Conference.
  • Despite its withdrawal, it had a significant impact on the nationalist movement and mobilised masses across India.

question:
Who among the following freedom fighters hoisted the Indian flag at the Gowalia Tank Maidan in Mumbai during the Quit India Movement?

SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Aruna Asaf Ali hoisted the Indian national flag at Gowalia Tank Maidan (August Kranti Maidan) in Mumbai on 9 August 1942, marking the beginning of the Quit India Movement.
  • Despite the arrest of most senior Congress leaders, including Gandhi and Nehru, she bravely led the protest and became a prominent face of the movement.
  • Her action symbolized defiance against British rule and inspired many to continue the struggle despite brutal suppression.
  • Due to her role, she is often called the "Grand Old Lady of the Independence Movement".

Additional Information:

  • The Quit India Movement was launched by the Indian National Congress at the Bombay session in August 1942.
  • Gowalia Tank Maidan later became known as August Kranti Maidan due to this historic event.

question:
Who among the following was the only martyr of the Quit India phase of the freedom movement who was hanged?

SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Kushal Konwar was the only martyr of the Quit India Movement (1942) who was hanged by the British.
  • He was a freedom fighter from Assam, and a committed Gandhian who believed in non-violence.
  • Despite his non-violent principles, he was falsely accused of involvement in a train sabotage incident during the Quit India agitation.
  • He was convicted without proper evidence and was hanged on 15 June 1943 at Jorhat Jail.
  • His sacrifice is remembered as a symbol of injustice under British rule and unwavering patriotism.

Additional Information:

  • Kushal Konwar was the President of the Sarupathar Congress Committee at the time of his arrest.
  • He accepted his fate with calmness and refused to appeal his sentence, remaining committed to the ideals of truth and non-violence.

question:
Which newspaper was founded by Mahatma Gandhi in South Africa in 1903?

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• Mahatma Gandhi founded the newspaper "Indian Opinion" in 1903 in South Africa.
  • It served as a weekly publication to spread awareness among the Indian community in South Africa about civil rights, discrimination, and Gandhi’s philosophy of Satyagraha (non-violent resistance).
  • The paper was published in multiple languages, including English, Gujarati, Hindi, and Tamil, to reach a wider audience.
  • It played a crucial role in mobilizing Indian settlers in South Africa and became a tool for political awakening.

Additional Information:

  • "Young India" and "Navajivan" were started later in India after Gandhi returned in 1915.
  • "Indian Opinion" laid the foundation for Gandhi’s role as a communicator and reformer.

question:
C Rajagopalachari led the Salt Satyagraha in which of the following states?

SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• C. Rajagopalachari, a prominent leader and close associate of Mahatma Gandhi, led the Salt Satyagraha in Tamil Nadu in 1930.
  • He organized a Salt March from Tiruchirappalli to Vedaranyam (also known as the Vedaranyam March), covering a distance of about 150 miles.
  • This march mirrored Gandhi’s Dandi March in Gujarat and aimed to defy the British salt laws.
  • Rajagopalachari and his volunteers made salt at Vedaranyam, openly violating colonial law, which led to their arrest.

Additional Information:

  • C. Rajagopalachari was the first Indian Governor-General of independent India.
  • The Vedaranyam Salt Satyagraha inspired regional participation in the national civil disobedience movement.
